Mature learners get ready for study

Leeds Trinity & All Saints welcomed 35 mature learners for a 5-day transitional Mature Student Summer School in September, to introduce them to the College, their subject area and specific study skills.
Students on the summer school, which forms part of Trinity & All SaintsÂ Widening Participation programme, are all about to embark on degree courses at the College.

The aim of the week was to raise attainment of the students and offer those who are returning to education after a break the opportunity to rediscover or develop skills that will enable them to get the most from their time at Trinity & All Saints.

Many mature learners are nervous about returning to education. Activities throughout the week addressed their fears and helped them to begin to overcome them and feel less apprehensive about starting their courses. A key benefit of the course is that they get to know other students and staff so they see some familiar faces during the first week of term.
The students also undertook an assessment as part of the summer school, which included compiling a reflective journal and a group presentation.

Amanda Ogilvie-Berry, School and College Liasion Officer, helped organise and run the Mature Learners Summer School. Amanda said, ÂWorking with mature learners is always a rewarding experience. You see them move from being utterly terrified and nervous on the first morning to developing confidence in their own ability, and a belief that they can actually do this degree. Thanks must go to all of those who were involved in the week and helped make it the huge success it was.Â

Feedback from participants showed that it had also been a rewarding week for the students involved. One of the learners commented, ÂI was dreading the presentation all week, but I know it was the best, most useful thing to help me develop confidence.Â
For more information on Widening Participation events please contact Amanda Ogilvie-Berry on 0113 283 7284 or a.ogilvie-berry@leedstrinity.ac.uk
